Description. One of the largest fern species, the ostrich fern can easily reach a height of 5 feet or more. Large fiddleheads emerge in spring as the fern emerges from dormancy. These will develop in to large, slightly scaly, sterile fronds that will persist through early fall. Matteuccia struthiopteris, with its exotic, palm-like appearance, is a wonderful addition to any moist woodland area or shade garden. It tolerates most soil types, but it will do best in slightly acidic, moist to wet soil that is rich in organic matter.

Ostrich Fern {10 Bare Root plants }. Matteuccia struthiopteris, commonly called Fiddlehead or Ostrich Fern, offers an erect, feathery plume of vibrant, lush green, divided, lanceolate fronds that arch gracefully outward into a symmetric clump. Edible tightly wound immature fronds (called fiddleheads) appear in spring, offering a delightful addition to your cooking repertoire as well as visual texture and interest to the garden. Fertile fronds are produced after the vegetative fronds and persist throughout the following winter; the spores shed in mid-winter.
